comments.commentBody:
Roger, what should we do when we find the find that lovely lady from Minnesota - and the millions of her spiritual cousins around the fruited plains - that John McCain found in 2008 when she said:

"I can't trust Obama. I have read about him and he's not, he's not uh — he's an Arab."

I suppose we could diplomatically say what John McCain said:

"No, ma'am. He's a decent family man [and] citizen that I just happen to have disagreements with on fundamental issues and that's what this campaign's all about. He's not [an Arab]."

It's always a good idea to bring your passport and get your rabies shots before venturing out into the fake heartland, the fake Bible Belt, Fake News Nation and that exceptionally American Assimovian territory where one's ignorance is just as good as actual knowledge.

We're going to need a bigger national IQ to get out of this ditch, and yet the Party of Stupid just keeps digging for dolts.

We all know you can't fix stupid, but the Republican Party does a fine job enhancing stupidity in their endless quest for nationally-assisted-political-suicide.

See Republistan, Americans - and enjoy the newest Russian republic !
This the sneering condescension that got Trump elected.

You made a very cogent suggestion-that America will need a bigger national IQ, and I might add-rather quickly. It is not going to happen in America now-and suggests that America has reached a point of national social,economic and cultural maturity as a state and has symptoms of taking on all of the trappings of a failed state. America does not have mechanisms in place to cope with social change and world cultural perturbations. The Trump answer to solve problems is to increase military and potential for war. This a symptom of lack of state problem solving ability in a changing world. The voting public's solution to what they see as problems will create more problems in the form of Trump-hence-a priori-much of the American public has provided the means-through ignorance-to make the problems worse.
There will be no solution for ignorance in a society-and that is the root cause of America's impending failure as a society. The model-now about 250 years old can no longer cope.

And which party has the teacher's union in their pocket?  I would think if the people stupid, you have no one but yourself to blame?   The people are not stupid, they are tired of, as I just wrote another, the favoritism being showed the yachts on SF Bay compared to their dinghies on the Mississippi.

the republicans have created a series of voting districts that benefit their party. There are many progressive thinking people in the state but their votes hardly count due to the gerrymandering and laws that keep impoverished rural voters (Native Americans in the main) without postal service or transportation to mail in or send their votes to the poll with those who own trucks, etc. These laws are to 'prevent fraud'.
Our federal officials, particularly Senators Flake and McCain who strongly support Trump and his cabinet choices and policies, have refused to schedule any citizens meetings to listen to voters, and apparently do not intend to have any meetings at the next recess. We have had to rely on our courts but even there our senators want to dismantle the 9th circuit court with its large no. of justices appointed by Clinton and Obama. The destruction of our public school system and our independent courts will be the end of any remaining democracy in Arizona.

I might have a shred of respect for the likes of Mike Pence IF he would accept that providing access to all methods of contraception, and allowing health care professionals to work with their patients are important ways to reduce the number of abortions, in addition to giving women agency over their lives. Pence and his fellow zealots, however, prefer to impose their religious beliefs on women.

Paul:

Both S. Korea and Japan have substantively agreed to sublimate their military to American hegemony.

The U.S. is at the center, the hub of a vast, parallel hub and spoke economic and security system that we created after WWII in part, as a response to the cold war.

Like it or not, we made a deal with the NATO countries in Europe, Japan and South Korea in Asia and Australia and New Zealand in the South Pacific. Essentially, economically we gave away access to our very rich markets in exchange for geopolitical hegemony over this vast alliance. Many of these nations, regions, protected their own economies even while they were dumping vast tons of trade into the U.S. The U.S. policy makers figured that because the U.S. was more advanced and competitive, it could give up some ground to these countries in more traditional sectors in exchange for penetration in advance sectors. Some times this hurt, as with autos with Japan and S. Korea, some times it worked out well, as in the 1990s and the export of computers and software. NATO and the other alliances basically put the militaries of the 25 of the 30 or so richest countries of the world's military at our disposal for the almost token price of reasonable/rational diplomacy. NATO makes its members supremely secure and that in turn has facilitate trade and prosperity for most members.

Unfortunately this model began to be undermined by the Neocons in the BushJr administration & so has begun to unravel. Now comes Trump.

Here we are in 2017, and the controlling party in government regards women as pretty much nothing more than baby-makers.

I wonder why the GOP is so threatened by the idea of a woman wanting to have control over her own body and parenthood. What is it that makes the GOP go absolutely nuts when a female runs for president? Let's not kid ourselves; quite a few Trump voters just didn't like the idea of a woman running things.

The GOP long ago lost the battle (Or battles.) of ideas. Because of that, it employs tactics that are designed to suppress the rights of certain kinds of people. That it simultaneously oppresses women and manages to have millions of women tacitly go along with their oppression is amazing to me.

For me, it makes about as much sense for a woman to choose to be a Republican as it does for a woman to choose to be a Catholic or a Muslim. I simply don't understand.
It is called indoctrination. It begins when you are a small child and continues through adulthood. It is hard to push back against what you have been taught was right all your life.

You're wrong about conservatives losing the battle of ideas. People have become dissatisfied with liberal anarchy, and will continue to choose conservativism in greater numbers.

Look at the assault at Middlebury College, and ask anyone if they want this? Only about 10% of the people are that crazy.

Amazing that someone would read an article like this and walk away dwelling on phantoms and conspiracies bubbling up within the U.S. government.  Even Kim Jung-un would be envious of the blind devotion of Trump's followers.
Amazing reporting, David Sanger and colleagues at the Times. Thank you for keeping us informed.

It is often the case twwren that fact and reality based news takes a while to investigate and put all the pieces together.  It doesn't just rely on making up some fantastic claim that fits into a Tweet and then sending it out based on a momentary impulse.

Here are two high school students willing to shell out $100 for tickets to a rock concert, but expecting me, a taxpayer, to protect them from recreational sex. What a way to start off a responsible life of caring, sharing and nurturing others.

In my day, in heavily Catholic Connecticut, when all contraceptive use was illegal in Connecticut, the chapter on human development was not bound into our high school biology textbooks by State law, and at my elite men's college in Massachusetts, the only course on sex was in our senior year.
Spoken like a true fossil and proud misogynyist, Steve.

I love this logic!  People go to concerts in Minneapolis all the time, so why should a dime of my tax dollars go to Minnesota?  I'm never going to Minnesota again, so why should I have to pay for your highway repairs? Take care of your own roads, why don't ya?
I wouldn't be talking to much about righteous Catholicness at the moment... https://nyti.ms/2locvcr

Well mike, at least you have acknowledged that Obama and Clinton took the issue seriously and took serious steps to address the North Korean nuclear issue.  Meanwhile Trump's strategy seems to be summarized by him bellowing "not good" when asked about it.

President Clinton did nothing about the North Korean proliferation of nuclear weapons, President Bush also did nothing as did President Obama  all these leaders had the opportunity and weapons to squash the North Koreans.  Now the new American president is left with dealing with an adolescent,  megalomaniac who would destroy America beginning with California, the West Coast and the world.  And we thought the Mullahs of Iran were nuts!  Thanks NYT"s for telling the world about a classified weapons program.

The Times has a big part of the responsibility for this. The Times cheered for all of the presidents who had wishful thinking.

Now, the Times should step up and urge Japan and South Korea to get the bomb.

I'm confused....are you referencing '45'....."Now the new American president is left with dealing with an adolescent, megalomaniac who would destroy America' or Kim Jong-un? Starts to get vexatious at times......

"And we thought the Mullahs of Iran were nuts!"

I never get the obsession with Iran. They are not nice people, but we know where they live.

Even Korea seems just a perennial irritant.

How about the ~50 A-bombs rattling around failed state Pakistan? recent home of bin Laden.

North Koreans don't have a history of happy suicide.

Can you say the same about the various clubs of loony Muslims in Pakistan?

Uhm, it's a good idea Titian because N. Korea is an unstable nuclear power with the ability to deliver it against other countries in Asia, and on the pathway to having a thermonuclear ICBM. Add to that equation a new, untested and unpredictable (at best) U.S. Presidential Administration which will be guiding policy against this threat.

In other words, newsworthy.

a diplomatic approach would be to declare any attack from  north korea on us interests could well cause collateral damages on Chinese infrastructure and immediate economic consequences on the most Asian nations .......

If trump has a "world view", his world is confined within his business organization.  Had you lived in another place at another time, you could have put your talent for hagiography to work in the service of someone like Stalin.

Situations like this have many causes. And most of them are local. Nevertheless,  Americans need to understand that the Sudan has been subjected to US meddling for decades and that the US was instrumental in facilitating South Sudan's secession from the Sudan. Ever since the middle 1950s, when African nations began to come to independence, they have been agreed on respect for each other's territorial integrity. The United States took it upon itself to violate that understanding. Rather than working with the Sudan to create a political settlement, the US government gave into pressure from various US advocacy groups, including many who call themselves Christian, to create a state in the South Sudan that almost no one thought was viable. The US government and those advocacy groups have to accept a substantial share of the blame for what has unfolded in South Sudan since independence.

It is unfortunate. But South Sudan is just show casing the stark inability of the Negroid and Nilotic races to govern themselves. For a long time the Arabs from the Sudan and Egypt in the east to Morocco and Mauritanian in the west have been treating the original inhabitants of the Maghreb like second class citizens or worse. Having South Sudan secede was the only solution. Unfortunately, the political elite like in most sub-Saharan Africa sees this an avenue to carve fiefdoms.

"Cry for the beloved continent"
leave it alone !!!!!

Splitting nations or empires up by ethnic or religious identity has a long history of stoking prolonged and bloody conflict. It inherently sanctions intolerance and persecution of minorities, and has led to disaster from India to post-WW1 Europe.

It's the Bush father that owns the oil company in south Sudan. Their ( South Sudan ) president is a right hand of the bush family. Google him and you will see with a cowboy hat that he wears proudly because it was a gift from an American president. South Sudan's president is a bush ( or an American ) guy.

Dear Moria,

Songwriter is referring to the funding of the rebel groups in South Sudan by lobbies in the USA to achieve the succession of The Sudan, since chevron and other oil manufacturing giants were banned from the country and replaced by Chinese firms by the dictatorship in the north. He is also referring to the British colonization divide and conquer and closed border policies in creating disasters in post colonial future of its colonies. The wars in Africa have always been connected to western businesses interests wether the french, the Americans, ...

Its the people in your end of the world who don't realize that the luxury of the life you live is sometimes paid by the misery of Others around the world, and that those others are human beings, wether in dictatorships in the Middle East, Africa, Latin America, ... Ahhh
Stop buying oil there and stop selling guns and weapons there.
There type of thing has been nonstop since WWI ended by both parties.
Gee, I wonder where the cowboy hats came from.
Say OIL!
You are misinformed. You might read some history before making such a misguided comment.
"Building ministries" is the CIA. What part of deep state pandering and profiting from oil theft don't you understand?
